section.title: NSA Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5 Rev. 4.2 / Aug 2011

abstract.para: The National Security Agency/Central Security Service (NSA/CSS) is home to America's codemakers and codebreakers. The Central Security Service was established in 1972 to promote a full partnership between NSA and the cryptologic elements of the armed forces.

NSA/CSS is unique among the U.S. defense agencies because of its government-wide responsibilities. NSA/CSS provides products and services to the Department of Defense, the Intelligence Community, government agencies, industry partners, and select allies and coalition partners.

NSA's Information Assurance Mission focuses on protecting National Security Information and Information Systems, in accordance with National Security Directive 42. As such, their lines of business include: IA Guidance, Security Engineering, and Integrated Computer Network Operations. OS Lockdown supports many of the items identified in their Guide to the Secure Configuration of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5
http://www.nsa.gov/ia/guidance/security_configuration_guides/current_guides.shtml.

para.literallayout: 187 Total number of line items in guideline 124 Items at least partially addressed by OS Lockdown 63 Items not addressed by OS Lockdown

table.title: NSA Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5 Rev. 4.2 / Aug 2011

row.entry: Create Separate Partition or Logical Volume for /tmp
Create Separate Partition or Logical Volume for /var
Create Separate Partition or Logical Volume for /var/log
Create Separate Partition or Logical Volume for /var/log/audit
Create Separate Partition or Logical Volume for /home
Add nodev Option to Non-Root Local Partitions

member.xref: Use NODEV Option for Non-root Partitions
Use NOSUID and NODEV for Removable Media

row.entry: Disable Modprobe Loading of USB Storage Driver
Disable Mounting of Uncommon Filesystem Types

member.xref: Disable Mounting of Uncommon Filesystem Types

row.entry: Verify Permissions on passwd, shadow, group and gshadow Files
Verify that All World-Writable Directories Have Sticky Bits Set
Ensure SUID Core Dumps are Disabled
Enable Execute Disable (XD) or No Execute (NX) Support on 32-bit x86 Systems
Restrict Root Logins to System Console
Limit su Access to the Root Account

member.xref: Limit Access To Root From Su

row.entry: Block Shell and Login Access for Non-Root System Accounts
Verify that No Accounts Have Empty Password Fields
Verify that No Non-Root Accounts Have UID 0

member.xref: Set Password Aging on Active Accounts

row.entry: Remove Legacy ’+’ Entries from Password Files

member.xref: No Plus Entries in Password Files

row.entry: Set Password Quality Requirements, if using pam cracklib
Set Lockouts for Failed Password Attempts

member.xref: Lock account after three failed login attempts

row.entry: Ensure that No Dangerous Directories Exist in Root’s Path
Ensure that User Home Directories are not Group-Writable or World-Readable
Ensure that User Dot-Files are not World-writable
Implement Inactivity Time-out for Login Shells
Disable and Remove SETroubleshoot if Possible
Disable MCS Translation Service (mcstrans) if Possible
Disable Automatic Loading of IPv6 Kernel Module
Monitor Syslog for Relevant Connections and Failures
Confirm Existence and Permissions of System Log Files
Enable Auditing for Processes Which Start Prior to the Audit Daemon
Configure auditd Rules for Comprehensive Auditing
Remove .rhosts Support from PAM Configuration Files
Disable the irda Service if Possible
Disable the Raw Devices Daemon if Possible
Restrict Permissions on Files Used by cron
Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Logins

member.xref: SSHD Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Logins

row.entry: Disable X Windows at System Boot
Disable the CUPS Service if Possible
Disable Printer Browsing Entirely if Possible
Disable Services Used Only by NFS
Restrict NFS Clients to Privileged Ports
Create Warning Banners for All FTP Users
Use user Security for Servers Not in a Domain Context
Disable Guest Access and Local Login Support
Set the Allowed Authentication Negotiation Levels
